This is what nx does after install
`"postinstall": "node ./decorate-angular-cli.js && ngcc --properties es2015 browser module main",`

title: `@storybook/vue` v6 disables typechecking for `@vue/cli-plugin-typescript` v4.4
body:
**Describe the bug**
When using both `@storybook/vue` v6+ and `@vue/cli-plugin-typescript` v4.4, typechecking is disabled

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behaviour:

0. Start a brand new vue project with typescript using vue cli v4
0. Introduce a type violation by replacing the `msg` prop in the default `HelloWorld.vue` component with:
    ```js
    {
        type: String,
        validator( value: string ): string {
            return value.startsWith( 'Hello' );
        },
        default: 'Hello World',
    }
   ```
0. Execute `npm run build`
   **Note:** At this point checks should still fail.
0. Ensure that in your `package.json`, the package `@vue/cli-plugin-typescript` is set to version `~4.4.0` (if not, change the version number and reinstall packages)

   **Note:** At this point checks should still fail.
0. Install storybook v6: `npm i -D @storybook/vue`

title: Deprecated addons should have a stable release compatible with Storybook 6
body:
Deprecated addons like `addon-notes` don't have a 6.0 release, and their existing 5.x releases have dependencies on Storybook 5. This leads to mixing 2 versions of Storybook.
IMO, these addons should receive a 6.0 release using semver ranges for the storybook dependencies (as they won't get released again for each storybook release), otherwise the deprecation does not work well and it is effectively an immediate removal.

comments.body:

title: A story suddenly disappears when using CDKPortal in component
author: enk0de

comments.body:
@huneeeee You probably need to make a repro of the problem or at least more detail. I am using `CdkPortal` in multiple components and multiple different ways of using it. None of my stories have had a problem with it.

My assumption is that it has something to do with how your story is defined, but nothing about that is in the description. There were some issues that caused stories to disappear in early versions of Storybook `6.0.0-rc-*`.

I have noticed that Storybook seems to be either hiding some errors or ignoring some for an unclear reason, but I haven't narrowed down a consistent reproduction that shows a hidden problem that is clearly not my fault, yet.

I use `CdkPortal` in multiple components with working stories. Some use it to just swap between a few components in a `cdkPortalOutlet`, some insert components into various `CdkOverlay`s, etc, so I don't think its the problem.

Do you have any warnings in the devtools?

I have had some stories not displaying, with the only indication that anything was wrong, is warnings logged in the devtools.
The warnings that caused my problem happened to be caused by the package `@ngneat/until-destroy`, and any story that used a component that used that package would not display the story in the sidebar. The most recent version of that package doesn't cause that problem any more. I think it had something to do with a difference in how Angular 10 defines the components and the JIT compiler couldn't handle it, but even though `ng serve` and `ng build` didn't error, it wasn't really a Storybook issue.

Since the warning had nothing pointing to the story or component, I narrowed down my problem by modifying the `stories` glob in `.storybook/main.js` to only match the specific file with the story that didn't load. It was inconvenient, but that was how I realized the warnings were indicating my problem. Before doing that, I had been ignoring the warnings, assuming they were just from stories I hadn't updated yet.

title: Allow meta viewport tag to be customised
body:
### Bug or support request summary

We have an existing website that we are adding React components to. The website has a viewport tag with the initial scale set to `0.6`:

```
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=0.6">
```

We would like to set Storybook to use the same `initial-scale` value so that components rendered there appear the same size as they will on the website.

We've tried adding a viewport tag to `preview-head.html` but the browser (Chrome) seems to ignore it in favour of the one that Storybook defines above it in the document head.

It would be great if we had the option of replacing the meta viewport tag without our own one.

- @storybook/react 5.3.9

### Affected platforms 

- Chrome on macOS running using the devtools to run as an iPhone 6 device.

title: Setting select knob via query param with numbers returns string
body:
**Describe the bug**
When using a select knob with _**all**_ numbers say

```ts
const myNumber = select<Rotation>(
  'number',
  {
    'zero': 0,
    'one': 1,
    'two': 2,
  },
  0,
);
```

When using the knobs via the UI, the `myNumber` value will return the **_number_** `0` when selected.

When setting the knobs from the query params, the `myNumber` value will return the **_string_** `"0"`.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Add select knob of numbers to story
2. Go to story
3. Click `copy` button to copy url for all knobs
4. Paste in new window
5. Notice the resolved value of the select is a _**string**_ NOT _**number**_

**Expected behavior**
Select could check the type of all the values provided and if all are `numbers` coerces/parse the value to a number type, like the way the `number` knob does.

Or could have an optional param to say `isNumber` but that seems messy

**Current Workaround**

```ts
export const numberSelect = <T extends number>(
  name: string,
  options: { [s: string]: T },
  value: T,
  groupId?: string,
): T => (parseInt(select<T | string>(name, options, value, groupId) as string) as T) || value;

export const myNumber = numberSelect<number>(
  'number',
  {
    zero: 0,
    one: 1,
    two: 2,
  },
  0,
);
```

**System:**
```
Environment Info:

  System:
    OS: macOS Mojave 10.14.6
    CPU: (16) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i9-9980HK CPU @ 2.40GHz
  Binaries:

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

I just spent a few minutes trying to debug my storybook integration until I noticed that I had (through careless copy&paste) registered the `@storybook/addon-viewport` in my `addons.js` file – but I had not npm-installed it.

I know this was stupid by me for not setting things up in a thorough way 🤦‍♂️

Still, running `npm run storybook` produced a webpack built without throwing any errors or giving hints:

```sh
info @storybook/vue v4.1.11
info
info => Loading presets
info => Loading presets
info => Loading custom .babelrc
info => Loading custom .babelrc
info => Loading custom addons config.
info => Loading custom webpack config (full-control mode).
webpack built 6ee5b84edc8caae1b3bb in 3449ms
```

Of course, opening Storybook on the assigned `localhost` resulted in a `Cannot get /` message.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

I would have liked the setup to at least give me a warning that the addon I registered wasn't available instead of just swallowing that error (which must have happened somewhere!?).

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

I can't really think of an alternative. I **do** think swallowing any errors is not a good thing to do, though 😄  

**Are you able to assist bring the feature to reality?**

Maybe, I don't know? I'm not familiar with the code base & webpack. Would still give it a shot.

**Additional context**

As you might see, I have a custom webpack and babelrc (nothing special, "just" alias resolving & some `sass` files being loaded), but I don't think that relates (or should relate) to the issue described here.
author: HerrBertling

comments.body: That's a good idea @HerrBertling, would you like to raise PR? I can help you if needed.

I'm not sure of the correct way to fix this but after some digging around I managed to find a way to output the suppressed webpack errors for addons.

File - ./node_modules/@storybook/core/server/dev-server.js line 125 - This promise.all is swallowing all errors from the two queued promises, the way I got it to bubble out was to change it to:

```
Promise.all([
    managerPromise.catch(e => e),
    previewPromise.catch(e => e)
  ]).then(([managerStats, previewStats]) => {
```

This should allow storybook to serve correctly and the webpack error can be seen in the browser console

title: Not scrolling in full screen mode on iOS
body:
The iframe is not scrolling on iOS. this could be fixed by setting its parent to `overflow: auto` and `-webkit-overflow-scrolling: touch`

potentially modifying the following object in `/lib/ui/src/modules/ui/components/layout/index.js` as seen below. 

```
const fullScreenPreviewStyle = {
  position: 'fixed',
  left: '0px',
  right: '0px',
  top: '0px',
  zIndex: 1,
  backgroundColor: '#FFF',
  height: '100%',
  width: '100%',
  border: 0,
  margin: 0,
  padding: 0,
  overflow: 'auto',
  webkitOverflowScrolling: 'touch',
};

title: Knobs Addon: support JavaScript objects (rather than JSON)
body: Allow the `object` knob to support a JavaScript object rather than a JSON object. That way, the user doesn't have to manually type out a full, valid JSON object, which can be quite laborious.

title: extract default webpack and publish as package
body:
We see people using our webpack config by including it, and we even document it.
`@storybook/react/dist/server/config/webpack.config`

But reaching deep into a package is a bad practice, because it's fragile, and makes it harder for us to refactor.

We should publish the default webpack config as it's own package.

title: Middleware should enforce trailing / or use <base href>
body:
Hi!  Given:

```js
const storybook = require("@kadira/storybook/dist/server/middleware").default;
app.use("/stories", storybook(".storybook"));
```

Navigating to `/stories` results in a `404` of `manager.bundle.js` because it's loaded at `/static/manager.bundle.js` instead of `/stories/static/manager.bundle.js`.

There are two solutions to this:

- Add `<base href="${req.path}/" />` or equivalent in the the HTML.
- Enforce the trailing slash in the middleware.

I can submit a PR for either depending on your preference.
